p: The results also suggest that tyrosinase inhibition positively correlates with TPC and DPPH free radical scavenging activity, suggesting that flavonoid compounds present in S. sipylea are responsible for the tyrosinase inhibitory activity of the species. Furthermore, a correlation between the reduction in extract polarity and % elastase inhibition was observed at 500 Î¼g/mL. The EO at the same concentration presented the highest value (%) of elastase inhibition (20.28%). A reduction in elastase activity up to 70% has been observed for the essential oils having eugenol, cinnamaldehyde, and geraniol [ 52]. From the data obtained in this study, and in comparison, with those reported in the literature, one can argue that the activities observed for the EO of S. sipylea are not only due to its major components but may also be due to synergistic effects with other minor components. Therefore, it can be argued that the EO of S. sipylea is a potential inhibitor of proteolytic enzymes and can be used in dermo-cosmetic formulations. However, further studies are needed for its stability in aqueous solutions and its toxicity.
